text:
President Trump believes Apple could manufacture iPhones in the U.S., according to Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt

Should Apple manufacture iPhones in the U.S.?
They will sell more because of a better quality product

@AskPerplexity how can this affect the manufacturing cost comparing to the manufacturing in China? can you make a quick analysis on how this could affect the product pricing?  what could be the increase ratio?

Obviously, The President doesn't understand the cost of which Apple would have to price these devices to make a proffit.

There would be no more $1k dollar devices talking a minimum of $3,500 and that's being generous...

When you consider the cost of moving facilities, building

As Tim Cook said in an interview, they (Apple) can’t find the same level of consistency with workers here in the U.S. to do with the consistency in assembly, the same way they can in China.

He said you’re lucky if you can find a handful here in factories, whereas China’s
High labour costs, plus higher tax rate is a disaster. It can’t be until those things changed.

A few years ago, Tim Cook said Apple works with China not for cheaper labor, but because of its highly specialized expertise in advanced tooling. China has a large pool of skilled workers, enabling mass production on a scale hard to match with the smaller talent pool in the U.S.
They fucking SHOULD
Well for the sake of consumers, YES!

I don't believe American workers would be willing to work under the same conditions as Chinese workers. It seems to me that Donald Trump doesn't realize the sheer scale of the logistical and economic challenges involved in relocating iPhone production. It's not something that can

Tim Cook said it himself. 
China is no longer the Cheap Labour country. 
They just have more skilled Engineers and Workers. 
They have the Manufacturing Technology to support Scale and Efficiency.
They have the supply chain to provide the Materials. 

The US does not.

I think Apple should explore U.S. manufacturing beyond TSMC's chip production due to tariffs, but shifting iPhone production domestically will likely raise prices short-term due to high costs and supply chain issues, unless offset by incentives.

It would be great if they did, but it would take a while to get the all production lines, manufacturing capacity, and all the other things that revolve around that up and running.

It can be done, just not overnight.
If they can yes or at least some products. The phones aren't too bad if you trade in yearly but still a bit high for entry level phones for our kids. We need break proof screens for the kids.
They should but they won’t because they are a public corpo. Gotta maximize that shareholder value.
Of course they should. Since no one will make them, he’s automation and make even a better profit margin.
Yes please.
it's possible for specialize models but mass production is NOT possible - Chinese are paid a fraction of US workers
Will the price go up? Or will it lower? If the price shoots up, then no. They r already expensive as it is.
Yea but at what cost?
Wouldn’t that quadruple the cost?

The logistics of scaling up such a move while maintaining the quality and speed of production seem too  complicated. It would be more feasible for only a partial shift rather than a full-scale relocation.
